TITLE: Defining Basic XML Structure for Spring Bean Configuration
DESCRIPTION: This snippet shows the basic structure of XML-based configuration metadata for Spring beans. It includes the root <beans> element and demonstrates how to define individual beans.
SOURCE: https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-ai/blob/main/spring-ai-commons/src/test/resources/text_source.txt#2025-04-20_snippet_0

LANGUAGE: XML
CODE:
```
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<beans xmlns="http://www.springframework.org/schema/beans"
    xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"
    xsi:schemaLocation="http://www.springframework.org/schema/beans
        https://www.springframework.org/schema/beans/spring-beans.xsd">

    <bean id="..." class="...">  
        <!-- collaborators and configuration for this bean go here -->
    </bean>

    <bean id="..." class="...">
        <!-- collaborators and configuration for this bean go here -->
    </bean>

    <!-- more bean definitions go here -->

</beans>
```

TITLE: Retrieving Beans from ApplicationContext in Java
DESCRIPTION: Example showing how to create an ApplicationContext from XML configuration files, retrieve a configured bean instance, and use it in a Java application.
SOURCE: https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-ai/blob/main/spring-ai-commons/src/test/resources/text_source.txt#2025-04-20_snippet_7

LANGUAGE: java

TITLE: Implementing ApplicationContextAware for Method Injection in Kotlin
DESCRIPTION: Kotlin implementation of the ApplicationContextAware interface showing how to manage bean dependencies with different lifecycles. The CommandManager class demonstrates prototype bean creation through application context.
SOURCE: https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-ai/blob/main/spring-ai-commons/src/test/resources/text_source.txt#2025-04-20_snippet_80

LANGUAGE: kotlin
CODE:
```
class CommandManager : ApplicationContextAware {

    private lateinit var applicationContext: ApplicationContext

    fun process(commandState: Map<*, *>): Any {
         val command = createCommand()
         command.state = commandState
         return command.execute()
    }

    protected fun createCommand() =
               applicationContext.getBean("command", Command::class.java)

    override fun setApplicationContext(applicationContext: ApplicationContext) {
         this.applicationContext = applicationContext
    }
}
```

TITLE: Configuring Constructor-Based Dependency Injection in Spring XML
DESCRIPTION: XML configuration for constructor-based dependency injection defining an ExampleBean with constructor arguments. The configuration demonstrates both nested ref elements and attribute-based referencing for constructor parameters.
SOURCE: https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-ai/blob/main/spring-ai-commons/src/test/resources/text_source.txt#2025-04-20_snippet_45

LANGUAGE: XML
CODE:
```
<bean id="exampleBean" class="examples.ExampleBean">
      <!-- constructor injection using the nested ref element -->
      <constructor-arg>
           <ref bean="anotherExampleBean"/>
      </constructor-arg>

      <!-- constructor injection using the neater ref attribute -->
      <constructor-arg ref="yetAnotherBean"/>

      <constructor-arg type="int" value="1"/>
</bean>

<bean id="anotherExampleBean" class="examples.AnotherBean"/>
<bean id="yetAnotherBean" class="examples.YetAnotherBean"/>
```

TITLE: Using @Lookup Annotation with Bean Name in Java
DESCRIPTION: Java class demonstrating how to use the @Lookup annotation with a specific bean name to implement method injection in an annotation-based component model.
SOURCE: https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-ai/blob/main/spring-ai-commons/src/test/resources/text_source.txt#2025-04-20_snippet_84

LANGUAGE: Java
CODE:
```
public abstract class CommandManager {

      public Object process(Object commandState) {
           Command command = createCommand();
           command.setState(commandState);
           return command.execute();
      }

      @Lookup("myCommand")
      protected abstract Command createCommand();
}
```

           this.beanOne = beanOne;
      }

      public void setBeanTwo(YetAnotherBean beanTwo) {

}

TITLE: Defining Beans with Groovy Bean Definition DSL
DESCRIPTION: Example of using Spring's Groovy Bean Definition DSL to define beans in a .groovy file. This configuration style is equivalent to XML definitions and supports Spring's namespaces.
SOURCE: https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-ai/blob/main/spring-ai-commons/src/test/resources/text_source.txt#2025-04-20_snippet_6

LANGUAGE: groovy
CODE:
```
beans {
    dataSource(BasicDataSource) {
         driverClassName = "org.hsqldb.jdbcDriver"
         url = "jdbc:hsqldb:mem:grailsDB"
         username = "sa"
         password = ""
         settings = [mynew:"setting"]
    }
    sessionFactory(SessionFactory) {
         dataSource = dataSource
    }
    myService(MyService) {
         nestedBean = { AnotherBean bean ->
               dataSource = dataSource
         }
    }
}
```

TITLE: Configuring Scoped Proxy for Session Bean in Spring XML
DESCRIPTION: This XML configuration demonstrates how to create a proxy for a session-scoped bean and inject it into a singleton-scoped bean. It uses the <aop:scoped-proxy/> element to instruct the container to create a proxy for the userPreferences bean.
SOURCE: https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-ai/blob/main/spring-ai-commons/src/test/resources/text_source.txt#2025-04-20_snippet_106

LANGUAGE: XML
CODE:
```
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<beans xmlns="http://www.springframework.org/schema/beans"
    xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"
    xmlns:aop="http://www.springframework.org/schema/aop"
    xsi:schemaLocation="http://www.springframework.org/schema/beans
        https://www.springframework.org/schema/beans/spring-beans.xsd
        http://www.springframework.org/schema/aop
        https://www.springframework.org/schema/aop/spring-aop.xsd">

    <!-- an HTTP Session-scoped bean exposed as a proxy -->
    <bean id="userPreferences" class="com.something.UserPreferences" scope="session">
        <!-- instructs the container to proxy the surrounding bean -->
        <aop:scoped-proxy/>
    </bean>

    <!-- a singleton-scoped bean injected with a proxy to the above bean -->
    <bean id="userService" class="com.something.SimpleUserService">
        <!-- a reference to the proxied userPreferences bean -->
        <property name="userPreferences" ref="userPreferences"/>
    </bean>
</beans>
```

TITLE: Implementing ApplicationContextAware for Method Injection in Java
DESCRIPTION: Example showing how to implement ApplicationContextAware interface in Java to manage bean dependencies when lifecycle requirements differ between singletons and prototypes. The CommandManager class demonstrates getting new Command instances from the application context.
SOURCE: https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-ai/blob/main/spring-ai-commons/src/test/resources/text_source.txt#2025-04-20_snippet_79

LANGUAGE: java
CODE:
```
public class CommandManager implements ApplicationContextAware {

    private ApplicationContext applicationContext;

    public Object process(Map commandState) {
         Command command = createCommand();
         command.setState(commandState);
         return command.execute();
    }

    protected Command createCommand() {
         return this.applicationContext.getBean("command", Command.class);
    }

    public void setApplicationContext(
               ApplicationContext applicationContext) throws BeansException {
         this.applicationContext = applicationContext;
    }
}
```

TITLE: Implementing Command Manager with ApplicationContextAware in Java
DESCRIPTION: Java implementation of a CommandManager class that uses ApplicationContextAware to handle prototype bean injection. The class manages Command instances through Spring container awareness, demonstrating method injection patterns.
SOURCE: https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-ai/blob/main/models/spring-ai-openai/src/test/resources/text_source.txt#2025-04-20_snippet_78

LANGUAGE: java
CODE:
```
//  a  class   that   uses   a  stateful    Command-style       class   to  perform    some   processing
package    fiona.apple;

//  Spring-API      imports
import    org.springframework.beans.BeansException;
import    org.springframework.context.ApplicationContext;
import    org.springframework.context.ApplicationContextAware;

public    class   CommandManager       implements     ApplicationContextAware          {

      private    ApplicationContext        applicationContext;

      public   Object    process(Map      commandState)      {
           //  grab   a  new   instance    of  the   appropriate     Command
           Command    command    =  createCommand();
           //  set   the  state    on  the  (hopefully     brand    new)   Command    instance
           command.setState(commandState);
           return    command.execute();
      }

      protected     Command    createCommand()       {
           //  notice    the   Spring   API   dependency!
           return    this.applicationContext.getBean("command",                 Command.class);
      }

      public   void   setApplicationContext(
                 ApplicationContext        applicationContext)        throws    BeansException       {
           this.applicationContext          =  applicationContext;
      }
}
```

TITLE: Implementing Factory Method Dependency Injection in Java
DESCRIPTION: Java implementation of ExampleBean with a static factory method for bean creation. The class has a private constructor and a static factory method that accepts dependencies and returns an instance of ExampleBean.
SOURCE: https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-ai/blob/main/spring-ai-commons/src/test/resources/text_source.txt#2025-04-20_snippet_49

LANGUAGE: Java
CODE:
```
public class ExampleBean {

      // a private constructor
      private ExampleBean(...) {
           ...
      }

      // a static factory method; the arguments to this method can be
      // considered the dependencies of the bean that is returned,
      // regardless of how those arguments are actually used.
      public static ExampleBean createInstance(
           AnotherBean anotherBean, YetAnotherBean yetAnotherBean, int i) {

           ExampleBean eb = new ExampleBean(...);
           // some other operations...
           return eb;
      }
}
```

TITLE: Implementing Factory Method Dependency Injection in Kotlin

class ExampleBean private constructor() {

           // a static factory method; the arguments to this method can be

           // regardless of how those arguments are actually used.
           @JvmStatic
           fun createInstance(anotherBean: AnotherBean, yetAnotherBean: YetAnotherBean, i: Int): ExampleBean {

               return eb
           }
      }
}

TITLE: Implementing Command Manager with ApplicationContextAware in Kotlin
DESCRIPTION: Kotlin implementation of a CommandManager class that uses ApplicationContextAware to handle prototype bean injection. Provides the same functionality as the Java version but with Kotlin-specific syntax and features.
SOURCE: https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-ai/blob/main/models/spring-ai-openai/src/test/resources/text_source.txt#2025-04-20_snippet_79

LANGUAGE: kotlin
CODE:
```
//  a  class   that   uses   a  stateful    Command-style       class   to  perform    some   processing
package    fiona.apple

//  Spring-API      imports
import    org.springframework.context.ApplicationContext
import    org.springframework.context.ApplicationContextAware

class    CommandManager      :  ApplicationContextAware          {

      private    lateinit    var   applicationContext:        ApplicationContext

      fun  process(commandState:          Map<*,   *>):   Any   {
           //  grab   a  new   instance    of  the   appropriate     Command
           val   command    =  createCommand()
           //  set   the  state    on  the  (hopefully     brand    new)   Command    instance
           command.state       = commandState
           return    command.execute()
      }

      //  notice    the  Spring    API  dependency!
      protected     fun  createCommand()       =
                 applicationContext.getBean("command",               Command::class.java)

      override    fun   setApplicationContext(applicationContext:                ApplicationContext)         {
           this.applicationContext          =  applicationContext
      }
}
```

TITLE: Using c-namespace for Constructor Arguments in Spring XML
DESCRIPTION: Shows how to use the c-namespace for configuring constructor arguments in Spring beans. Compares traditional constructor-arg elements with the more concise c-namespace attributes approach.
SOURCE: https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-ai/blob/main/spring-ai-commons/src/test/resources/text_source.txt#2025-04-20_snippet_72

LANGUAGE: XML
CODE:
```
<beans xmlns="http://www.springframework.org/schema/beans"
      xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"
      xmlns:c="http://www.springframework.org/schema/c"
      xsi:schemaLocation="http://www.springframework.org/schema/beans
           https://www.springframework.org/schema/beans/spring-beans.xsd">


      <bean id="beanTwo" class="x.y.ThingTwo"/>
      <bean id="beanThree" class="x.y.ThingThree"/>


      <!-- traditional declaration with optional argument names -->
      <bean id="beanOne" class="x.y.ThingOne">
           <constructor-arg name="thingTwo" ref="beanTwo"/>
           <constructor-arg name="thingThree" ref="beanThree"/>
           <constructor-arg name="email" value="something@somewhere.com"/>
      </bean>


      <!-- c-namespace declaration with argument names -->
      <bean id="beanOne" class="x.y.ThingOne" c:thingTwo-ref="beanTwo"
           c:thingThree-ref="beanThree" c:email="something@somewhere.com"/>


</beans>

TITLE: Configuring Collection Properties in Spring XML
DESCRIPTION: Example of configuring different collection types (Properties, List, Map, Set) as bean properties in Spring XML configuration. Demonstrates how to set Java Collections using <props>, <list>, <map>, and <set> elements.
SOURCE: https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-ai/blob/main/models/spring-ai-openai/src/test/resources/text_source.txt#2025-04-20_snippet_57

LANGUAGE: XML
CODE:
```
<bean id="moreComplexObject" class="example.ComplexObject">
      <!-- results in a setAdminEmails(java.util.Properties) call -->
      <property name="adminEmails">
           <props>
                 <prop key="administrator">administrator@example.org</prop>
                 <prop key="support">support@example.org</prop>
                 <prop key="development">development@example.org</prop>
           </props>
      </property>
      <!-- results in a setSomeList(java.util.List) call -->
      <property name="someList">
           <list>
                 <value>a list element followed by a reference</value>
                 <ref bean="myDataSource" />
           </list>
      </property>
      <!-- results in a setSomeMap(java.util.Map) call -->
      <property name="someMap">
           <map>
                 <entry key="an entry" value="just some string"/>
                 <entry key="a ref" value-ref="myDataSource"/>
           </map>
      </property>
      <!-- results in a setSomeSet(java.util.Set) call -->
      <property name="someSet">
           <set>
                 <value>just some string</value>
                 <ref bean="myDataSource" />

TITLE: Configuring Constructor Arguments Using c-namespace in Spring XML
DESCRIPTION: XML configuration demonstrating c-namespace usage for concise constructor argument configuration. The example shows both traditional format and c-namespace format for the same constructor arguments.
SOURCE: https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-ai/blob/main/models/spring-ai-openai/src/test/resources/text_source.txt#2025-04-20_snippet_71

LANGUAGE: XML
CODE:
```
<beans xmlns="http://www.springframework.org/schema/beans"
      xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"
      xmlns:c="http://www.springframework.org/schema/c"
      xsi:schemaLocation="http://www.springframework.org/schema/beans
           https://www.springframework.org/schema/beans/spring-beans.xsd">


      <bean id="beanTwo" class="x.y.ThingTwo"/>
      <bean id="beanThree" class="x.y.ThingThree"/>


      <!-- traditional declaration with optional argument names -->
      <bean id="beanOne" class="x.y.ThingOne">
           <constructor-arg name="thingTwo" ref="beanTwo"/>
           <constructor-arg name="thingThree" ref="beanThree"/>
           <constructor-arg name="email" value="something@somewhere.com"/>
      </bean>


      <!-- c-namespace declaration with argument names -->
      <bean id="beanOne" class="x.y.ThingOne" c:thingTwo-ref="beanTwo"
           c:thingThree-ref="beanThree" c:email="something@somewhere.com"/>


</beans>
```

TITLE: Defining Method Replacement in Spring XML Configuration
DESCRIPTION: XML configuration for deploying a class with method override using Spring's <replaced-method> element. It demonstrates how to replace a method in a bean with an implementation from another bean.
SOURCE: https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-ai/blob/main/models/spring-ai-openai/src/test/resources/text_source.txt#2025-04-20_snippet_86

LANGUAGE: XML
CODE:
```
<bean id="myValueCalculator" class="x.y.z.MyValueCalculator">
    <!--   arbitrary    method    replacement      -->
    <replaced-method name="computeValue" replacer="replacementComputeValue">
         <arg-type>String</arg-type>
    </replaced-method>
</bean>

}

TITLE: Adding Repositories to Gradle Build
DESCRIPTION: Adds the required repositories, including Spring Milestones, to a Gradle build file. This configuration is necessary for accessing Spring AI dependencies.
SOURCE: https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-ai/blob/main/src/prompts/update-to-m7.txt#2025-04-20_snippet_3

LANGUAGE: groovy
CODE:
```
repositories {
    mavenCentral()
    maven {
        url = uri("https://repo.spring.io/milestone")
        mavenContent {
            releasesOnly()
        }
    }
}
```

TITLE: Configuring BasicDataSource Bean in Spring XML
DESCRIPTION: This snippet shows how to configure a BasicDataSource bean with properties for database connection. It demonstrates setting string values for driver class, URL, username, and password.
SOURCE: https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-ai/blob/main/models/spring-ai-openai/src/test/resources/text_source.txt#2025-04-20_snippet_50

LANGUAGE: XML
CODE:
```
<bean id="myDataSource" class="org.apache.commons.dbcp.BasicDataSource" destroy-method="close">
    <!-- results in a setDriverClassName(String) call -->
    <property name="driverClassName" value="com.mysql.jdbc.Driver"/>
    <property name="url" value="jdbc:mysql://localhost:3306/mydb"/>
    <property name="username" value="root"/>
    <property name="password" value="misterkaoli"/>
</bean>
```

TITLE: ApplicationContext Usage in Java
DESCRIPTION: Demonstrates how to create and use ApplicationContext in Java to configure beans and retrieve instances.

LANGUAGE: java
CODE:
```
// create and configure beans
ApplicationContext context = new ClassPathXmlApplicationContext("services.xml", "daos.xml");

// retrieve configured instance

// use configured instance
List<String> userList = service.getUsernameList();
```

TITLE: Updating Model Starter Artifact ID in Maven
DESCRIPTION: Example of updating the OpenAI Spring Boot starter artifact ID in Maven to follow the new naming convention. The pattern changes from spring-ai-{model}-spring-boot-starter to spring-ai-starter-model-{model}.
SOURCE: https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-ai/blob/main/src/prompts/update-to-snapshot.txt#2025-04-20_snippet_6

LANGUAGE: xml
CODE:
```
<!-- BEFORE -->
<dependency>
    <groupId>org.springframework.ai</groupId>
    <artifactId>spring-ai-openai-spring-boot-starter</artifactId>
</dependency>

<!-- AFTER -->
<dependency>
    <groupId>org.springframework.ai</groupId>
    <artifactId>spring-ai-starter-model-openai</artifactId>
</dependency>
```

TITLE: Configuring Properties Instance in Spring XML
DESCRIPTION: This snippet shows how to configure a java.util.Properties instance within a Spring bean definition. It demonstrates setting key-value pairs for JDBC properties using the <value> element.
SOURCE: https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-ai/blob/main/models/spring-ai-openai/src/test/resources/text_source.txt#2025-04-20_snippet_52

LANGUAGE: XML
CODE:
```
<bean id="mappings"
    class="org.springframework.context.support.PropertySourcesPlaceholderConfigurer">

    <!-- typed as a java.util.Properties -->
    <property name="properties">
         <value>
               jdbc.driver.className=com.mysql.jdbc.Driver
               jdbc.url=jdbc:mysql://localhost:3306/mydb
         </value>
    </property>
</bean>
```

TITLE: Configuring Data Access Objects in Spring XML
DESCRIPTION: Example of configuring data access objects (DAOs) in a Spring XML configuration file. Shows bean definitions for JPA-based DAOs.
SOURCE: https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-ai/blob/main/models/spring-ai-openai/src/test/resources/text_source.txt#2025-04-20_snippet_6

CODE:

<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<beans xmlns="http://www.springframework.org/schema/beans"
    xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance"
    xsi:schemaLocation="http://www.springframework.org/schema/beans
        https://www.springframework.org/schema/beans/spring-beans.xsd">

    <bean id="accountDao" class="org.springframework.samples.jpetstore.dao.jpa.JpaAccountDao">
        <!-- additional collaborators and configuration for this bean go here -->
    </bean>

    <bean id="itemDao" class="org.springframework.samples.jpetstore.dao.jpa.JpaItemDao">
        <!-- additional collaborators and configuration for this bean go here -->
    </bean>

    <!-- more bean definitions for data access objects go here -->

</beans>
```

TITLE: Default Blog Service Implementation
DESCRIPTION: Example of a service class with initialization method and property validation.
SOURCE: https://github.com/spring-projects/spring-ai/blob/main/models/spring-ai-openai/src/test/resources/text_source.txt#2025-04-20_snippet_111

LANGUAGE: Java
CODE:
```
public class DefaultBlogService implements BlogService {
    private BlogDao blogDao;

    public void setBlogDao(BlogDao blogDao) {
         this.blogDao = blogDao;
    }

    // this is (unsurprisingly) the initialization callback method
    public void init() {
         if (this.blogDao == null) {
               throw new IllegalStateException("The [blogDao] property must be set.");
         }
    }
}
```
